pr_title: Update Attributes API to comply the spec

timeline.bodyText: Simple if would be much simpler :)
timeline.author: iNikem
jkwatson

timeline.bodyText: Why other values like null array is not removed?
timeline.author: bogdandrutu

replies.bodyText: I think along these lines, if we're using null to model deletion, we should just store null directly, not an attribute value with a value of null.
replies.author: anuraaga

replies.bodyText: Because null values inside arrays are meaningful. Since the Attributes API does not create null attributes, it cannot exist a null value but only a value that contains an AttributeValue with null. Does it make sense?
replies.author: thisthat

replies.bodyText: No, it does not make sense. What if the "array" is null, not the value inside the array?
replies.author: bogdandrutu

replies.bodyText: The "array" cannot be null. Resource uses the Attributes class for storing attributes which creates always an object for arrays: https://github.com/open-telemetry/opentelemetry-java/blob/master/api/src/main/java/io/opentelemetry/common/Attributes.java#L204
replies.author: thisthat

replies.bodyText:
Very strange behavior for arrays then:

  
    
      opentelemetry-java/api/src/main/java/io/opentelemetry/common/AttributeValue.java
    
    
         Line 331
      in
      78ed649
    
    
    
    

        
          
           if (stringValues == null) { 
        
    
  


We replace with empty array/list.... Not too much consistency.
replies.author: bogdandrutu

replies.bodyText: General Java guidelines are to never return null for a collection, but use an empty one (per Josh Bloch in Effective Java). So, I think this behavior is a good one.
replies.author: jkwatson

replies.bodyText: We discussed about this. It is not we return null, it is we get null and add an entry with empty collection, why then not add an entry with empty string?
replies.author: bogdandrutu

replies.bodyText:
I have uniformed the handling of null in 18e3719. The following cases are dropped (or removed if the key was already present):

null strings, e.g. (String) null
new arrays with 0 length, e.g. new String[0]
null arrays, e.g. (String[]) null

Instead, the following are stored as attributes:

Empty strings
Arrays with null values as members, e.g. new String[] {null}
replies.author: thisthat

timeline.bodyText: It might be easier just to call isEmpty() rather than comparing explicitly to an empty list. And, this makes me think we could have an isEmpty() method on the AttributeValue, and then you can skip all of the switch branches and have the logic much more simple.
timeline.author: jkwatson

timeline.bodyText:
I thought we got on the same page but see this didn't change yet - can't we filter in the producer here?
https://github.com/open-telemetry/opentelemetry-java/blob/master/api/src/main/java/io/opentelemetry/common/ImmutableKeyValuePairs.java#L58
timeline.author: anuraaga

replies.bodyText: In the last SIG meeting, we agree on keeping the same behavior for all the interfaces that can create attributes.
replies.author: thisthat

replies.bodyText:
I may finally understand, is it that here
https://github.com/open-telemetry/opentelemetry-specification/blob/b4e327c3fbc62be811036cac572e4cc0d57dd560/specification/trace/api.md#set-attributes
where we discuss Attribute values of null are considered to be not set and get discarded as if that SetAttribute call had never been made., this only refers to Spans? But Attributes are more general and could permit null values in other cases? It seems very confusing that we would support null attributes (not talking about as an implementation detail for modeling deletion for example but as actually exported value), but if that reading is correct than I agree we wouldn't filter in the producer, and may need to reclarify the spec.
replies.author: anuraaga

timeline.bodyText: we could just have this be concrete and return false and only override it for the types that support emptiness.
timeline.author: jkwatson
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -244,6 +244,15 @@ public double getDoubleValue() {
    */
   public abstract Type getType();
 
+  /**
+   * Returns {@code true} if the {@code AttributeValue} contains a {@code null} value or it is an
+   * empty array.
+   *
+   * @return {@code true} if the {@code AttributeValue} is empty.
+   * @since 0.8.0
+   */
+  public abstract boolean isEmpty();

timeline.bodyText: How about shouldAdd and return false when it shouldn't? Having trouble following this method
timeline.author: anuraaga

replies.bodyText: I would suggest calling it isInvalidKeyValue. This way, we don't need to negate its results in the setAttribute methods.
replies.author: thisthat

replies.bodyText: doNotAdd could be ok too, though I don't know if I personally find it more readable than a negation. But the main point is to not have key in the method name since it's not only checking the key but doing something special based on the value as well. Just describing the return value (whether to add or not) seems fine to me.
replies.author: anuraaga

timeline.bodyText: This is pretty slow but maybe we don't need to worry.
timeline.author: anuraaga

replies.bodyText: You are right. However, I don't expect the removal of attributes to be a frequent operation.
replies.author: thisthat

timeline.bodyText: Having this method, which looks like a simple query method, also have the side effect of removing data is very surprising. The name of this method should reflect that it is potentially an update operation. Also, how does this handle the fact that the key might be in the data twice at this point? Don't we need to iterate through the entire array to remove all instances of the key?
timeline.author: jkwatson

replies.bodyText: You are right! I have overlooked that dedup is done as the last thing in the builder.
replies.author: thisthat

timeline.bodyText: rather than repeating this logic over and over again, can we just call the setAttribute method with the attribute value above?
timeline.author: jkwatson

timeline.bodyText: could we just return a static final AttributeValue instance, rather than creating a new one for each call?
timeline.author: jkwatson

replies.bodyText: I've overlooked a simple thing like that 😅
replies.author: thisthat

replies.bodyText: hey, that's why we review each others code. :). Easy to miss stuff like this when you're in the weeds.
replies.author: jkwatson

timeline.bodyText: interesting. now that empty arrays are explicitly allowed, I wonder if "isEmpty" is no longer the right name. Maybe isMissing ?
timeline.author: jkwatson

replies.bodyText: or maybe just isNull() since that's literally what we're checking for now.
replies.author: jkwatson
